content.body: rubys: any thoughts on my suggested issue closures?
othermaciej: he was only here about 60 seconds
oh, no, rubys is still here
rubys2 left
Hixie: yeah, he just changed nicks
othermaciej: you might be interested in this: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-font/2009JulSep/1238.html
in fact, it would be good to get some feedback
roc: we discussed it briefly among web folks and font folks
oh good
http://www.jfkew.plus.com/webotf/webotf-test.html too
roc: we are not at all enthusiastic about implementing a new font format
roc: and grabbing only chunks of it at a time would be pretty hard to shoehorn into our font infrastructure
you don't have to grab only chunks of it at a time
roc: if all other browsers want to push something, we won't block it, but I don't think we are going to actively endorse any new format
ok
thanks
google's in pretty much the same position -- we are fine with TTF.
if operating systems add support for WebOTF, we would probably follow suit
but on its own, it doesn't really seem to solve any pressing problems
we are also fine with TTF/OTF, and would not consider WebOTF an improvement
but we are less opposed to it than EOT or anything EOT based, since it does not seem to have DRM-like characteristics
i'm back
Hixie, are you sure that "Sean Hogen" in the Acknowledgements section shouldn't be "Sean Hogan"?
hi!
heycam: i am not
(i remember seeing someone with the latter name send mails, but not the former)
what's the question?
irc archives appear to be down
rubys: I wanted to get your thoughts on my suggested closures of old issues, but I decided to just make a proposal for how to proceed with them on public-html
rubys: that being said, your input is still welcome if you have any

rubys: regarding your comment in the poll, the reason i removed that issue marker was that i was under the impression that the issue had been resolved as part of the compromise maciej set out -- removing the issue marker was one of the things jf and maciej agreed to as far as i understood it
rubys: and i didn't see your e-mails about it (there was a lot of traffic at the time, i must have missed one)
othermaciej: where is the proposal?
hixie: we clearly have a different idea of what closed means, but that's OK
rubys: oh, I guess I didn't send it yet
I guess that would explain why I couldn't find it.
yes, I do have thoughts...
rubys: my suggestion was going to be, close ISSUE-5, ISSUE-6, ISSUE-9, ISSUE-10, ISSUE-11, ISSUE-12, ISSUE-13, ISSUE-16, ISSUE-17, ISSUE-20, ISSUE-26 and ISSUE-28 on Monday if there are no objections
and I was planning to ask the team contacts to give me issue tracker edit rights to do it
oh, I can give you that now.
but I wouldn't suggest any sudden closure. Weren't you complaining a short while back about a particular vote being rushed? :-)
(I sent emails justifying closing each of those issues and soliciting feedback.)
oh, I think you are aright on all counts except for the one that Julian owns.
if you would like to suggest a different process for closing them, then I'm fine with that
and if nobody steps forward and agrees to work an item, it should be closed.
I think some reasonable period to object to closing is an adequate process, I am willing to make the time period whatever you think is best, if it's not unreasonable long

it looks like I'm chairing again on thursday, my plan was to announce that the issues that you identified that have no owners will be closed by the next thursday unless somebody steps forward to owning it.

I'm willing to leave Julian's open if he insists on it, although I think an issue about an old feature proposal he had is not the right way to represent the fact that he'd like to review a related section of the spec and give some feedback
he seems to agree that there won't be any major change.
the issue is pretty explicitly about a particular kind of major change, so it doesn't seem to represent his intent
that being said, I am satisfied to keep it open for now
though at some point, Julian's intent to do some review can't block Last Call, if he continues not to do it
totally agreed on that last point

rubys: OK if I send email summarizing this discussion? ("Issues to be announced at Thursday's telecon, and closed next Thursday except for ones where someone objects and steps up to own it." basically)
(n=me⊙idn) has left #whatwg
you can now edit issues.  I love the work you have done, just make sure that you give people an opportunity.
I'm trying to be extremely conservative in issues that I propose to close, and I intend to give everyone adequate opportunity to object

as I said, I was going to include it on the announce I was sending out tomorrow, but if you feel you want to go ahead, that's fine.  I feel that announce is low traffic and there is no excuses to miss an email (me glances towards hixie :-))
What about those of us who only read public-html and not announces? :)
then you get to read it later (in the minutes :-))

I think I'll send it separately and mention that you will also mention the details in the announcement, since I think there are people who will be interested, but habitually skip (or at best skim) the announcements
rubys: oh you sent your comment in an agenda e-mail? i don't read those, they seem to never change.
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Aug/0315.html
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Aug/0330.html
no, my comment wasn't in those.  Chris's agenda emails are formulaic, but I try to add more 'spice' to mine.
oh i saw your e-mail of those two, but it didn't seem to be a question, so i decided it'd be better for everyone if i didn't add fuel to the fire
othermaciej: I totally agree about moving 12 and 20 from issues to bugzilla on testcases
the first one was from laura, and i'm still waiting for her to explain how i wasn't cooperating before i reply to her e-mails
as i'm tired of sending e-mails with questions, and never getting replies
yet getting called on not replying to questions
anyway, as i said, the reason i didn't include the issue marker was that was the agreement with jf and maciej

I made it clear then that I still view the issue as open.  I tried to encourage you to add back the issue box, and later I tried to encourage manu not to proceed with the poll.  Seem to be batting 000 these days. :-)
considering the summary issue open is a huge mistake imho
there's no direction from this point that doesn't make more people less happy
so if we want to change the spec at this point, it pretty much has to be a vote
I don't think JF and I specifically said either to remove the marker or to keep it, and I personally don't care
considering it closed invites Formal Objection.  Much better to give people rope and all that.  And sometimes they surprise you.
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Aug/0017.html
JF clearly asked for the mark, and Ian clearly agreed.
that was long before maciej's compromise
and indeed Ian added the marker at that point
which you accepted, but not everybody did.  such a hasty process creates ill will
if only there were a way to avoid having a hasty process on technical issues right before WD
othermaciej: want me to dig up all the times recently where you were complaining about a vote being too fast? :-)

rubys, I think pushing to have warnings in the spec about open issues for summary and, previously, longdesc, has set a silly precedent that has lead us to this time wasting effort to vote on the inclusion of transient warnings that won't last longer than one WD cycle, let alone help to resolve the actual issues at hand.
Lachy: have you looked at the poll lately?
yeah, I know Hixie's draft is ahead
so why get upset and argue?
Precedent?
rubys: the meaning of my statement was supposed to be - I think there is indeed a way to avoid having a hasty process on technical issues right before WD, several ways, and we should do one of those
because I'm annoyed with this whole heartbeat issue having taken 4 weeks of valuable time that could have been spent finding real solutions, rather than meaningless nonsense
there are only two issues that I'm really worried about.  Issue-35 and Issue-74.
rubys: btw do you still intend to do the review you said you'd do?
Lachy: so don't spend your valuable time on it.
rubys: (just asking to know how to plan for the next few months)
I no longer see calling out sections as an effective way to proceed.
k
what's your new plan for establishing consensus?
it seems to me the blocker on issue-35 at the moment is not controversy on how to proceed, but rather blocking on a PFWG decision
we can (and should IMO) find ways to be more pro-active about unblocking progress
both 35 and 74 are blocked on PFWG
for 74, I believe good progress is being made on proposing a solution
and the solution may require little or no change to the spec besides editorial text giving examples
Dashiva, yes, that's what I meant. I always spell that word wrong
http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/actions/133
at least, that is what I have heard from my sources involved closely in those discussions
rubys: I'm surprised you're not really worried about issue 41
41 has no concrete proposal.
Lachy: I wasn't correcting you, I was semi-answering rubys
anyway, sorting out the chaff will make it easier for the group to have a shared view of which issues are important to worry about
which is why I am starting with the low-hanging fruit
I'm thinking like a project manager - must get bug trendline to point in the right direction
othermaciej: that's great, just make sure that everybody has a thursday-thursday period to notice the impending closure.
not everybody has the bandwidth to keep up with the emails.
rubys: I think thursday-thursday is a fine timeline and I'll stick to that
I think that way, both primarily-email and primarily-telecon participants get a fair chance to have their say
exactly
I have no interest in keeping open issues for which there are no owners.
And for issues with owners, I want dates.
35 and 74 have dates in Nov and Dec, which is what concerns me.
would rather see progress than dates :-P
rubys: what's your new plan for establishing consensus?
close items with no owners, give issues with owners a chance, and then close the issues either when they complete or fail.
so the issue tracker's list of issues in the state Open (not Raised, not Pending Review, and not Closed) is the list of issues that need to be resolved before LC?
or do you mean the list of issues not marked Closed?
I think establishing committed owners and deadlines for the issues that remain after closing the low hanging fruit is a fine next step
that leaves the questions of what to do if the deadline is missed (can't let it slip indefinitely), and what to do if there are multiple competing concrete proposals
Hixie: after a bit of cleanup, I do see the issue tracker as being that.  And othermaciej is doing a fine job at kicking off that discussion.
rubys: which states are the ones i need to look at to see issues blocking LC?
I think Hixie is asking if issues marked as "Raised" or "Pending Review" are considered open in the sense of blocking LC
(it's not entirely clear to me what the distinctions are)
Raised means no owners.  Destined to be closed due to lack of interest unless somebody steps up.
Pending Review means that the owner considers his or herself done.  Also destined to be closed.
by what process will Destiny work its will?
Open are the key ones, and what is key is getting agreement.  Telling people that it is closed only pisses them off.
othermaciej: taking your list and giving people until a week from thursday to volunteer is a great process.

rubys: all right, then in my next pass I will consider all Raised and Pending Review issues for the chopping block if they do not get caught in the first pass (where I am hoping to find issues where no real dissent remains)
rubys: who owns issues with no action items?
(i'm assuming the people with action items own the issues with them)
If hybi were to create a generic bidirectional tunneling protocol, wouldn't that immediately get blocked in firewalls for the same reason the firewalls block non-http in the first place?
hixie: tell me which ones, and I'll demote to raised or find an owner.  I just demoted 60.
rubys: http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/issues/37 http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/issues/59
(Well, not immediately, but as soon as the firewalls change)
Hixie: it seems to me that based on what Sam said, issues with no action item should be given an opportunity to find an owner, who presumably thereby receives an action item
I will continue my review of open issues tonight
demoted 37.  Will kick Mike again about 59.
s/presumably/definitely/
i can volunteer to own 59 if you like. And then immediately announce I've done it. :-)
(the html5 spec has had an "author view" for a while now)
Hixie, I like that idea
Hixie: is it possible to produce a copy of your spec that has the "author view" as the default stylesheet?
Hixie: I suspect people will be a tiny bit more satisfied if they can follow a link to the "author view", even if there is no material difference
othermaciej: sure, that's technically trivial.
Is it possible generate a copy which excludes all the implementer stuff from the file, rather than just hiding it with a stylesheet?
That should make the file significantly smaller and at least partially resolve the issues people have with the monolithic spec

if nobody else volunteers for 59, it will get closed.  I would must rather have a situation where somebody (in this case Mike) was given every opportunity and failed rather than telling them NO and have them be convinced that the only reason why they failed was that they weren't given a reasonable opportunity.
people might be slightly even more satisfied with that, even though there is even less material difference
Lachy: technically yes, but someone would have to make the script to do it.
ok
I assume it would just take a small script to strip out any element with a class="impl" on it
we should give Mike the opportunity to weigh in on whether Hixie's author view (if it can be linked standalone) satisfies the goals he had for H:TML
Mike is traveling at the moment, but he does log on.  He also plans to be on Thursday's call.
Lachy: yes
Lachy: are you willing to volunteer to make that script
I wouldn't mind having Mike's H:TML draft published non-normatively in addition to an author only copy
othermaciej, maybe.
I might even be able to do it now, if I can base it one one of my existing scripts I use for generating the authoring guide
if someone actually makes the script, then we may be able to persuade Mike that the author view is a win-win solution
or if it does not meet some of his goals, we can ask him to articulate what those are
Hixie, if it works like this: cat source | author-view > author-only-source, will that fit into your tool chain?
Lachy: it has to be a web service for me to put it in my toolchain
Lachy: (i can't be parsing the html5 spec a dozen times at once on the local machine)
ok. Well, I will proceed under the assumption that such a simple system will be very easy to integrate into a web service
So you prefer to rely on a dozen remote machines to each parse it?
Philip`: yup
Philip`: so long as it's not mine :-P
doesn't understand why that system doesn't collapse constantly, since it has lots of potential points of failure
it sucks that we don't have a nicely integrated system that allows the source to be parsed just once and processed such that it results in multiple output files
Philip`: the only critical point of failure i don't control is pimpmyspec.net
should probably move the multipage splitter onto a proper server, rather than on an old machine in his parents' house over an ADSL line
Where's the fun in that?
Lachy: i have a number of preprocessing steps that happen before the source becomes valid HTML that can be parsed
Lachy: e.g. merging source files from whatwg.org/demos, filtering the references, etc.
I seem to be able to go from Hixie-source to w3c split out spec in about 15 seconds on a rather midling AMD e-machine that I purchased for $199 earlier this year.
http://www.tigerdirect.com/applications/searchtools/item-details.asp?EdpNo=4616541
wow, a lot of these actions have been open a long time
i wonder how to help people make progress on them
this BWTP thread looks like a textbook case of feature creep
roc: gonna vote in the HTML WG poll?
I encourage you to vote your conscience, despite the relative triviality of the issue at stake
roc: BWTP looks like feature creep to me too - I wonder if there is a middle ground that adds a few of the most useful features but otherwise is closer in simplicity to WebSocket Protocol
othermaciej: your wish is my command
hmm, and I missed the part about BWTP having "forgiving syntax"
othermaciej: if there are features that actually make sense to add, and don't put onerous requirements on server-side implementations that don't need those features, i hope we can add them
othermaciej: i haven't seen any such features yet
Hixie: I haven't had a chance to give it a close review
for now I am taking it on faith that being "like http" would make things easier for server-side implementations embedded in an existing Web server
but I don't have the context to evaluate the merit of this claim
and the corresponding claim as to the client side seems wrong
it certainly wouldn't make it easier for standalone servers
which i expect to be the common case
on the other hand, i've written a websocket server in 99 lines of perl
I would love to hear from someone in charge of a big existing infrastructure which would be easier for them
(although I suppose that risks enterprise-itis)
othermaciej: Bidirection Web Transfer Protocol vs Web Sockets?
dave_levin: yes

I don't know if I should bother to argue with the crazy people who think that instead of a ws: URI scheme (or similar), the URIs should just be http://ws.specific-magic-hostname.org?the-actual-url-goes-here
othermaciej: I'll see if I can find someone on the Google Talk team to look them over if that would be helpful. They sit pretty close to me.
dave_levin: it would be helpful if they could review websocket in general
othermaciej: ask someone who's actually in charge of actual infrastructure what would be easier for them ... do not ask their Architect

Hixie: Honestly, they were a bit slow on all of that, but I think they are ready to focus more on these issues. I'll talk to them.  I think Ukai has also been talking to someone on that team (since he has been working web sockets in WebKit).
cool
roc: i'm not sure we even have any of those :-)
roc: *shudder*
annevk42: the comment box on the poll seems like a good place to enumerate what's not factual about Manu's draft
I wonder if this poll will top our record for most total votes (which I believe is 88)
is surprised to find on review that neither anne nor james have voted yet
Looks like there is a boom in HTML 5 tutorials...
hsivonen: do you know what's up with this issue? is there still a conflict? http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/issues/38
looks fixed, nevermind
hsivonen: does ARIA still depend in any way on CURIEs?
(re http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/issues/51 )
othermaciej: AFAIK, no, but I'll check
othermaciej: can't find any mention of curie in the latest ARIA spec.
hsivonen: ok, thanks
wonders whether he has the stomach to review issues 46-60
this is an incredibly boring task, which the chairs should have long ago done or delegated :-(
indeed
othermaciej: thank you for doing it anyway
Issue 53 seems to have draft text now
issue 54 has been addressed
I'm not sure what to suggest for issue 48
issue 54 is pending the registration of about: URI scheme
yeah
I would close it, but some people wanted it kept open until that's done
I think I'll suggest raising a separate issue on registering the about: URI scheme, if registering the scheme needs to block Last Call
good idea
othermaciej: about ARIA specifically: ARIA was fixed to acknowledge similarity of role to "XHTML Role Attribute Module" without actually importing the definition
or we can track it in bugzilla, if a scheme registration doesn't need to block Last Call
do media type registrations normally get updated before or after LC?
I hope the pont of issue 56 is to update AWWW if it turns out that real-world URL processing conflicts with Architecture
s/pont/point/
I have no idea what issue-56 is about
but I believe the plan to defer to WEBADDRESS or IRIbis or whatever addresses it
if issue 56 needs to be an issue, it should be a TAG issue filed against Architecture
so the only ones I don't know what to do with are ISSUE-48 and ISSUE-53 out of this next batch
othermaciej: if you mean mime types, we let the IESG know that we're going to register them when we hit LC, then we register them at CR.
Hixie: ok, so a task on MIME type registration doesn't need to block LC?
Hixie: or do we need draft registration text before LC, and if so do we have it?
BWTP seems like a lot of feature creep :-(
othermaciej: the draft registrations for all the MIME types I'm aware that we need to register are all at http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#iana-considerations
Hixie: ok, sounds like the issue on registrations can be closed, the
I hope the ARIA folk handle their LC comments by either renaming @role to @aria-role or allowing the host language to use a more appropriate existing attr (in our case, @class)
hober: I don't think putting aria roles in @class is viable
too many existing pages would then appear to have an ARIA role accidentally
hober: renaming role isn't on the table
hober: hasn't been since Firefox 3.0 froze
hasn't finished reading the scrollback but notes that he has a script that strips non author view stuff from the spec somewhere
hmm. my email isn't appearing on public-html
jgraham: do you think it would be feasible to integrate it with Hixie's toolchain?
I also hacked together an anolis module to copy status annotations from the WHATWG data to a static spec
jgraham: awesome!
I haven't checked it works very properly or anything
I will continue to poke at it a bit
othermaciej: pobably
*probably
jgraham: it would be useful - so we can see if such a spec would satisfy those who want an author-only spec
jgraham, great, that means I can take that off my todo list for today
anyway, the content of my email to list was that issue-30 isn't controversial anymore, because WAI-CG agreed to the obsoletion of longdesc if aria-describedby gets in
hsivonen: I saw your email
hsivonen: I even replied to it
I may have seen it not-via-the-list
othermaciej: ok. then SMTP at my end isn't horked
biab
hsivonen: mails seem to be appearing in the archive out of order
(n=arun⊙adpsn) has left #whatwg
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-rdf-in-xhtml-tf/2009Aug/0070.html
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-rdf-in-xhtml-tf/2009Aug/0085.html
yeah i couldn't tell if he was unintentionally proving our point about prefixes being confusing, or if he was being sarcastic.
I can't tell what his point is, either, but the email looks very confused.
http://www.w3.org/2009/07/30-rdfa-minutes : "We need to structure it so that it's easy for the W3C to accept the RDFa IG. RDFa isn't controversial, so shouldn't be an issue."
what the? I've never known anyone to claim that <div xmlns:dc="..."> was invalid XML
fights the urge to reply to the anti-pattern thread and point out less than factual statements
hsivonen, which anti-pattern thread?
oh, on rdfa list
Lachy: on public-rdf-in-xhtml-tf
http://hoppipolla.co.uk/410/spec-annotated.html first cut with no headers or stylesheet and with all the removed sections and so on left in
the BWTP guys know that eventually the UTF-8 frame type won't be the only option available, right?
they're so fixated on it...
would it make sense to extend bogus comments to also include <% ?
apparently WebKit/Trident already does that
annevk42: is it guys or guy?
and e.g. http://www.lex24.ilsole24ore.com/Redazione/Riforma_cpc/Riforma.html would look better at the bottom
hsivonen, there's more on the hybi list
but fair enough
annevk42: Is that not quirks only, at least in WebKit?
no
jgraham, what have you added to that copy of the spec?
also at the top of that page, not just the bottom
ah, I see, a few sections have Status annotations
Lachy: It should in theory be all sections that have status annotations in the WHATWG draft but I may have missed some
jgraham: let's ship it!
s/I/my code/
jgraham, the one for the introduction is missing, which is the one I checked for first and didn't see
hsivonen, how do you feel about having <% besides <? ?
wait, that's weird. It is there
Lachy: I don't have the introduction do I?
It's in the header which I don't have
yeah, you do. It says:
Introduction
Status: Working draft
1 Background
the abstract is in the header
Oh yeah
annevk42: assuming that WebKit/Trident already does it, I'm open to trying it.
unless supporting it is really needed for compatibility reasons, I don't think we should
have Mozilla received any bugs about supporting it?
supportin gwhat?
<% as comments
roc, webkit and trident apparently support it
Lachy: no bugs against the HTML5 parser at least
http://brand.icxo.com/htmlnews/2007/07/11/919666_1.htm
http://yuanyunfu.artron.net/exhibi_2.php?aid=A0000016&wrkid=BRT000000033876
http://www.51234.org/sy/3777.html

Philip`, it depends on whether supporting that as a comment is really the best solution. If they're only testing it with browsers that do, then that would explain why they havne't noticed or fixed the error
the last one is a "reported attack page!"
and presumably they have no intention of outputting JSP into the HTML
it's pretty clear that it's error recovery that makes the error less obvious to authors
well, a) the cost is minor and b) it is far more likely they just tested in IE than anything else
the question is if Gecko and Opera are worse off by not doing it if Trident and WebKit do it
also, the implementation would be trivial
no new states. just another transition
Most of the <%...s seem to be in attribute values rather than in text content
assuming we are OK with the % in the trailing %> ending up in comment data
I don't think that matters one bit
I think the question we should be asking is if Microsoft and Apple would be willing to drop support for it
it's an error, but for the pages I've looked at so far not displaying <% is better
http://blog.pewitt.org/CommentView,guid,56fbd9c0-6c0b-4773-abb7-dafb40fae8a7.aspx
That one looks a bit like it intentionally wants to use <%...%> as a comment
Hixie: yt?
Lachy: After discussion with gsnedders|work I will convert the author view generator to a anolis module that runs before things like the toc are generated
jgraham: http://74.125.77.132/search?q=cache:5iAdTkTth4EJ:krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20090703+http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20090703&hl=en&client=opera&strip=1#l-1126
jgraham, ok
what's happened to krijn?
he's in hiding
The computer he logs things from isn't exactly the most stable. :/
given that nobody else seems to be willing to log, it's been pretty awesome for us :)
I filed a bug on the <% crap btw
Wait! This means the evil cabal can say anything!
Is Lachy around?
remysharp, yes
hi - I've got a link for you - discussion possible alternatives to the legend issue
ok
it's not for public consumption - I couldn't get a preview of the blog post - but here you go:
http://remysharp.com/figure-legend.html
Not for public consumption? By posting it here, you've made it public anyway
brucel: I've added your example in too: http://www.brucelawson.co.uk/tests/html5-details-label.html
sorry, not quite what I meant - as in it's a blog post
ah
it's not the "real" url, more that comments won't work! :)
screw it I can publish it now anyway.
remysharp, I'll take a look in a moment, just busy with some work stuff right now
np
This is the latest url anyway - with examples of alternatives to the legend in figure & details issue: http://remysharp.com/2009/08/12/saving-figure-detail/
remysharp, your claim about hgroup isn't quite correct
Should <iframe></iframe> fire an onload event?
okay, so it *would* come up in the TOC?
Lachy: enlighten me :-)
basically, using <hgroup> means that all the headings inside it are grouped, such that they only the top level heading within it will appear in the TOC
remysharp: hgroup comes up in the TOC as the highest ranked heading within
Right - so actually it's not a viable solution at all in my particular example - cheers.

so, e.g.

Foo

Bar

should appear in the TOC as "Foo"
updating post
whoops!
(n=remyshar⊙c3cvc): Remy Sharp
#jquery-ot #whatwg #jquery
irc.freenode.net :http://freenode.net/
End of WHOIS list.
remy_, I'm not a big fan of reusing <header> for this purpose. As I told brucel yesterday, it's not the right semantics.
Aye, he mentioned that too
I just want to get the alternatives up there.
My preference is label, but I want to see what screenreaders do when it's embedded in a form
you people should just be patience
yeah, it's good to have a discussion about the alternatives again to show that Hixie's stubbornness about using <legend> is not good
with time <legend> will be fine
I think that we're open to almost any solution as legend won't fly
time? in that time authors won't use legend
annevk42: I don't think that's a good answer
and there'll be a mess of solutions
jgraham, I think it is

annevk42, that's what Hixie said, but authors are going to push forward with whatever hacks they can to work around the problems today, and unless we come up with a real solution, the result with be a huge mess in the long run
People think that they ought to be able to use it today since it is not having any effect in UAs and will become frustrated and discouraged when they find that they cannot
by the time all the current browsers have been weeded out it's going to be well beyond 2022!!! :)
oh please
stop the drama
Especially given the long half life of legacy browsers
It will result in either no-one using the new elements (figure, details) or using header/ label anyway

Hixie's key issue is simply that he'd like to make "nonsensical" combinations of native markup and ARIA nonconforming
it's fine to let ARIA take precedence in behavior if someone actually does it
but ARIA apparently doesn't let host languages make any ARIA markup nonconforming
the idea being that if you tell ARIA that your radio button is a checkbox, you probably did something wrong
my understanding is that in the case on nonsensical combinations, non comforming is not only OK, it is preferred; furthermore, the host language takes precedence in everything but role.
